Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Auxiliary2AzureSearch can fail if downloads.v1.json is being written" (#8076) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: This is because it used `OpenReadAsync` to get a stream, which, in WindowsAzure.Storage, does sequential range requests with `If-Match`.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Deprecating TLS 1.0 and 1.1 on NuGet.org - Stage 2" (#7875) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
As announced in the blog post [here](https://devblogs.microsoft.com/nuget/deprecating-tls-1-0-and-1-1-on-nuget-org/), it's time to permanently remove support for TLS 1.0, 1.1.
Exact date in April is TBD and will be announced several weeks in advance.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Dependents] Add configurable cache time" (#8038) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Opened issue "Add 'Include verified packages' filter to Advanced Search" (#8075) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
We received customer feedback about adding an option to only return verified packages from reserved namespaces in the advanced search panel.

e.g, if a search for "WebAPI" is done, with that option enabled, only packages from Microsoft would be shown and not from other package authors.

This feature is related, yet not part of the #2636 Epic

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "API key generation should highlight 'owner' selection" (#7996) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
We have seen many support requests where authors were not able to push packages using API keys as those API keys were not scoped to the right owner. This happens when there are one or more orgs, the author belong to and want to publish the package against an organization account.

We would need to highlight the owner selection when there are ore than one owner to select from.

My recommendation is to make it an explicit selection without defaulting to the current owner. This way the author will be aware of the accounts options they want to select.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Rebuild Azure Search Index" (#8056) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: Rebuild the index to be able to enable future advanced search features.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Make statistical significant figures formatting culture-sensitive" (#8039) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:

Adds culture-awareness to string operations creating short numbers for Y-axis on graphs. Added culture cases to unit tests. Examples:

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Advanced search] Update .NET Core tool documentation" (#8074) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Current documentation says ([link](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/core/tools/global-tools#find-a-tool)):

> Currently, .NET Core doesn't have a tool search feature. Here are some ways to find tools:
> 
> * See the list of tools in the natemcmaster/dotnet-tools GitHub repository.
> * Use ToolGet to search for .NET tools.
> * See the source code for the tools created by the ASP.NET Core team in the Tools directory of the dotnet/aspnetcore GitHub repository.
> * Learn about diagnostic tools at .NET Core dotnet diagnostic tools.
> * Search the NuGet website. However, the NuGet site doesn't yet have a feature that lets you search only for tool packages.

We should update this once we release the advanced search feature.

Opened issue "NuGet.org V3 API endpoints should return a HTTP compliant etag" (#8071) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Currently, the V3 endpoints return an etag without any quotes. This is because V3 is CDN backed by Azure Blob Storage. Azure Blob Storage, prior to [API version 2011-08-18](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/rest/api/storageservices/version-2011-08-18) returns malformed etags without quotes. If you send `x-ms-version: 2011-08-18` or later you get proper quotes.

According [RFC 7232](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7232#section-2.3), etags must be surrounded by double quotes.

```powershell
PS C:\Users\jver\Desktop> $url = "https://api.nuget.org/v3-flatcontainer/newtonsoft.json/index.json"
PS C:\Users\jver\Desktop> (Invoke-WebRequest $url).Headers.ETag
0x8D764B46B9CE392
PS C:\Users\jver\Desktop> (Invoke-WebRequest $url -Headers @{ "x-ms-version" = "2009-09-19" }).Headers.ETag
0x8D764B46B9CE392
PS C:\Users\jver\Desktop> (Invoke-WebRequest $url -Headers @{ "x-ms-version" = "2011-08-18" }).Headers.ETag
"0x8D764B46B9CE392"
```

We could add a CDN rule that fixes this problem so that HTTP compliant clients can use the etags without problems.
- Add  `x-ms-version: 2011-08-18` request header to if not present and vary the cache by `x-ms-version`
- Wrap the response etag in quotes if not present
- Others?

/cc @erdembayar

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Cache grows indefinitely - add limit feature" (#9730) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
We have an internal project that delivers a Nuget cache from each nightly build.  I work on a project that consumes this Nuget package.  Our build process automatically updates the Nuget version, so we are always pointing at the latest (unless we are near a release and then we freeze auto-updates).

This means that every time I pull the latest changes and build, VS "restores (download/install)" the next Nuget package.

Problem is that this Nuget package is 186 MB compressed, ~600 MB uncompressed, so in the %userprofile\.nuget cache folder, there is 786 MB for each new version.  Then when you build, VS copies it to the "packages" subfolder directory in the solution folder.

:) can you see where I'm going?

I just this morning deleted about 50 GB of packages from these two cache locations.  My computer was running slowly and I finally figured out it was because of low disk space/fragmentation issues.  

**So, I would like to request that a feature to limit the size of the Nuget cache be added.**

It could be smart so that it prefers to keep at least one version of every package, and then prefers the latest.  I don't know if you have access to the "last used by a compile" metric at this level, but that might a good way to do it too.

There are some optimizations we could (and eventually will do) on our side to reduce the size of the package, but it takes time and devops work (even so, the minimum set of dlls required are ~160 MB uncompressed for x64).  The unconstrained cache size problem would just be lessened.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "NPM Install failed due to  ERR! code EMISSINGARG" (#9186) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Please read the following information before posting the issue.

## Before posting the issue...

* If you're having trouble with the NuGet.org Website, please post in [NuGetGallery issues](http://github.com/nuget/nugetgallery/issues)
* If you're having trouble with the NuGet client tools (the Visual Studio extension, NuGet.exe command line tool, etc.), you are in the right place.

Remove the content above here and fill out details below.

## Details about Problem

NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | VS UI | Package Manager Console | dotnet.exe):

NuGet version (4.5.0): also checked with other versions.

dotnet.exe --4.6.

VS version (if appropriate): 2015, 2017

OS version (i.e. win10 v1607 (14393.321)): WS 2012

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version: worked with same version earlier.

Project is running fine while we run from local and only issue comes when we build with team city.
Node js and npm version is same in teamcity server and local.

Thanks

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "IVsPackageInstallerServices.IsPackageInstalled  returns false on 1st call" (#9181) at NuGet/Home
Closed issue "Content files copied to output are not inherited by other projects" (#9176) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Using VS2019 and a solution with lots of csprojs,
I have created a NuGet package which just copies a exe file to /bin.

`<contentFiles>
  <files include="**/helper.exe" buildActions="Content" copyToOutput="true" />
</contentFiles>`

The package works fine, but if I reference the project in an other project, the exe file (contentFiles) is not copied.

Referencing the package in the top project is not an option, because it is still using the old package.json.

How do I get the content files copied to inherited projects?

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "CVE-2020-1340 - NuGet Gallery Spoofing Vulnerability" (#45) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
A spoofing vulnerability exists when the NuGet Gallery does not properly sanitize input on package metadata values. An attacker who successfully exploited the vulnerability could perform cross-site scripting attacks and run scripts in the security context of the user viewing the malicious content.

To exploit this vulnerability, an attacker with permissions to upload packages could publish specially crafted content on a gallery page.

The security update addresses the vulnerability by correcting how NuGet Gallery sanitizes input.

**MSRC Security Guidance:** [CVE-2020-1340](https://portal.msrc.microsoft.com/en-US/security-guidance/advisory/CVE-2020-1340)
**Security Update:** [v2020.06.09](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/releases/tag/v2020.06.09)
